intro: Leiothylax drummondii, commonly known as Drummond's rockcress, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, four-petaled flowers and capsule fruits. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils, often in arid or semi-arid environments. It has basal leaves that are linear to oblanceolate, and its flowers are usually pale yellow or greenish in color. Leiothylax drummondii is generally short-lived, with a lifespan of one to two years.
